docs.lead_paragraph: YOU might never know it from the nightly news, but the election on Tuesday is particularly important for older Americans. How the vote goes for the House and the Senate will help determine the kind of prescription drug coverage that retirees may receive, and whether conservatives can continue their drive to at least partly privatize the Social Security system. The new Congress will also face deep problems in Medicare, as well as the problem of the millions of people without any health insurance -- including many older Americans who are not yet eligible for Medicare.

headline.main: Older Voters Hear More Than War Drums

docs.abstract: Fred Brock column contends that despite scant news coverage, economic and social issues dominate older voters' thinking about many coming election races around nation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TWO heated debates about free trade took place here last week, yet they were so different they might as well have been on separate planets. The most visible one was at a meeting of trade ministers from the United States and 33 other countries, who tried to hammer out a road map for negotiating a free-trade zone from Canada to Argentina. The other was led by ordinary citizens.

headline.main: Outside Halls Of Power, Many Fear Free Trade

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation, which has been struggling to show that it knows how to fix its financial problems, reported an $877 million loss yesterday and said that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an informal inquiry into the company. The company said that the S.E.C. was looking into the 38 percent drop in its shares on Oct. 25. Cigna said that day that earnings shortfalls and ballooning expenses would cut operating profits sharply this year and next. The problems resulted from faulty customer service and mistakes in setting prices and expenses, according to Cigna's chief executive, H. Edward Hanway.

headline.main: Cigna Has $877 Million Loss And Reports S.E.C. Inquiry

docs.snippet: The Cigna Corporation, which has been struggling to show that it knows how to fix its financial problems, reported an $877 million loss yesterday and said that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an informal inquiry into the company.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Tenet Healthcare, one of the largest for-profit hospital chains, said yesterday that one of its California hospitals had been raided by federal officials seeking information for an investigation into unnecessary surgeries, including open-heart surgery, and possible Medicare billing fraud. Federal officials say there is reason to believe that ''many known and unknown patients have been victims of a scheme to cause patients to undergo unnecessary invasive coronary procedures,'' including artery bypass surgery and heart valve replacement surgery, according to an affidavit by the F.B.I.

headline.main: Tenet Hospital In California Is Searched By U.S. Agents

docs.abstract: Tenet Healthcare says its California-based Redding Medical Center was raided by FBI agents seeking information for investigation into unnecessary surgeries, including open-heart surgery, and possible Medicare billing fraud; Federal officials say there is reason to believe 'many known and unknown patients' have been victims of scheme to cause patients to undergo unnecessary invasive coronary procedures, including artery bypass surgery, and heart value replacement surgery; Tenet says it has no reason to believe accusations are true; agents search offices of Dr Chae Hyun Moon, director of cardiology, and Dr Fidel Realyvasquez Jr, hospital's chairman of cardiac surgery; photo (M)
